case_name: Commissioner of Income-tax, Bombay v. Provident Investment Co., Ltd., Bombay

facts.text: Civil Appeal No. 179 of 1954 filed in Supreme Court.

anchor.surface_text: CIVIL APPELLATE JURISDICTION Civil Appeal No. 179 of 1954. Appeal from the judgment and order dated March

facts.text: Appeal from Bombay High Court judgment and order dated March 12, 1953 in Income-tax Reference No. 43 of 1952.

anchor.surface_text: Appeal from the judgment and order dated March 12, 1953, of the Bombay High Court in Income-tax Reference No. 43 of 1952.

facts.text: Certificate granted by Bombay High Court under sub-s. (2) of s. 66A of the Indian Income-tax Act.

anchor.surface_text: K. Daphtary, Solicitor-General of India, G. N. Joshi and B. H. Dhebar, for the appellant. A. Palkhivala, D. H. Dwarkadas, J. B. Dadachanji, S. N. Andley and Rameshwar Nath, for the respondent. 1957. May 15. The Judgment of the Court was delivered by K. DAS J.-This is an appeal on a certificate granted by the High Court of Judicature at Bombay under sub-s.  2  of s. 66A of the Indian Income-tax Act  hereinafter referred to as the Act .

facts.text: Appellant is Commissioner of Income-tax, Bombay; respondent is Provident Investment Co., Ltd., Bombay (assessee company).

anchor.surface_text: The appellant is the Commissioner of Income- tax, Bombay, and the respondent is the Provident Investment Co., Ltd., Bombay, hereinafter referred to as the assesses companypany.

facts.text: Question: Whether assessee company made capital gain of Rs. 81,81,900 within meaning of s. 12B.

anchor.surface_text: The question which was referred to the High Court under s. 66 1  of the Act was this Whether the assessee companypany made a capital gain amounting to Rs. 81,81,900 within the meaning of s. 12B of the Indian Income-tax Act?

facts.text: Bombay High Court answered the question in the negative.

anchor.surface_text: The High Court answered the question in the negative. The appellant being dissatisfied with the judgment and order of the High Court asked for and obtained a certificate from the said High Court that the case is a fit one for appeal to the Supreme Court.

facts.text: Assessee company is private limited company, shares held by Maharaja Scindia of Gwalior and his nominees.

anchor.surface_text: The material facts may be very shortly stated. The assessee companypany is a private limited companypany, the shares of which were held by the then Maharaja Scindia of Gwalior and his numberinees.

facts.text: Assessee company was managing agent of Madhowji Dharamsi Manufacturing Co., Ltd. and Sir Shapurji Broacha Mills Ltd.

anchor.surface_text: At the material time, the assessee companypany was the managing agent of Madhowji Dharamsi Manufacturing Co., Ltd., hereinafter briefly referred to as the Dharamsi Company, and Sir Shapurji Broacha Mills Ltd., briefly referred to as the Shapurji Broacha Company.

facts.text: Assessee held all ordinary shares of Dharamsi Company and substantial majority of ordinary shares of Shapurji Broacha Company.

anchor.surface_text: The assessee companypany held all the companyversion shares of the Dharamsi Company and a substantial majority of the companyversion shares of the Shapurji Broacha Company.

facts.text: Dalmia Investment Company wrote two letters to assessee on September 14, 1946 offering to purchase 28,328 shares of Dharamsi at Rs.500/share + managing agency, and 75,212 shares of Shapurji Broacha + managing agency.

anchor.surface_text: The Dalmia Investment Company Limited, which will hereinafter be briefly referred to as the Dalmia Company, wrote two letters to the assessee companypany on September 14, 1946. In these two letters, the Dalmia Company offered to purchase 28,328 companyversion shares of the Dharamsi Company at Rs. 500 per share together with the managing agency, and also 75,212 companyversion shares of the Shapurji Broacha Company, together with the managing agency.

facts.text: Dalmia offer: both mills or neither, time limit till September 23, 1946 3 p.m., extended to September 30, 1946.

anchor.surface_text: We are number companycerned with the other details mentioned in the two letters, except this that the Dalmia Company made it clear that it would purchase both the mills or neither, and a time limit till September 23, 1946, 3 p. m. was imposed during which the offer would remain open. This time limit was, however, extended later up to September 30, 1946.

facts.text: Earnest money: Rs.20 lakhs for Dharamsi, Rs.30 lakhs for Shapurji Broacha on acceptance.

anchor.surface_text: The letter further stated 1144 On your accepting the offer, we will pay to you Rs. 20 lakhs in the case of the Dharamsi Company, Rs. 30 lakhs in the case of the Shapurji Broacha Company as and by way. of earnest money.

facts.text: Board of Directors of assessee met on September 26, 1946, accepted Dalmia offers, resolved Rs.1 crore as compensation for loss of managing agency.

anchor.surface_text: On September 26, 1946, there was a meeting of the Board of Directors of the assessee companypany. At that meeting, the Board companysidered the offers made by the Dalmia Company and resolved to accept the offers. The Board further stated in its minutes that out of the total amount received from the sale of the shares, a sum of Rs. 1 crore should be paid to the assessee companypany as companypensation for the loss of the managing agency of the two mills.

facts.text: Assessee wrote to Dalmia on September 30, 1946 accepting offers subject to immaterial condition; Dalmia sent drafts Rs.20 lakhs and Rs.30 lakhs same day.

anchor.surface_text: On September 30, 1946, the assessee companypany wrote to the Dalmia Company accepting the offers made, subject to a companydition which is number material for our purpose. On the same date, the Dalmia Company received the acceptance of the offers made by it and sent two drafts, one for Rs. 20 lakhs and the other for Rs. 30 lakhs.

facts.text: Dalmia wrote letter on October 7, 1946 modifying arrangement: assessee to resign managing agency instead of transferring it, no need for general meeting sanction.

anchor.surface_text: On October 7, 1946, the Dalmia Company wrote a very important letter to the assessee companypany. This letter said inter alia With reference to the interview our Solicitor Mr. Tanubhai had with your Mr. Wadia, we beg to record that it is number being agreed upon as follows in modification of the arrangement previously made between yourselves and ourselves In our letters of offer which have been accepted by you, it was arranged that the managing agency will be transferred either to us or to our numberinees. Now, instead of doing so by you, you as the present managing agents will give their  sic  resignation, so that at the time of delivery of the shares and payment of moneys, your managing agency will have companye to an end. In view of the above, it is number necessary to obtain any sanction of general meeting.

facts.text: Assessee accepted modified arrangement.

anchor.surface_text: The assessee companypany accepted the modified arrangement suggested by the Dalmia Company,

facts.text: On October 19, 1946, assessee wrote to Dharamsi and Shapurji Broacha resigning managing agency.

anchor.surface_text: and on October 19, 1946, the assessee companypany wrote to the Dharamsi Company and the Shapurji Broacha Company that it had decided to resign the office of the managing agency and accordingly tendered its resignation on that date.

facts.text: Balance consideration paid to assessee; value of managing agency computed at Rs.1 crore, no dispute; it was a capital asset, no dispute.

anchor.surface_text: The balance of the companysideration money was then paid to the assessee companypany, and it was number disputed that the. value of the managing agency was companyputed at Rs. 1 crore, number was there any dispute that the managing agency was a capital asset.

facts.text: Income-tax Officer computed capital gains at Rs.81,81,900 on Rs.1 crore and demanded tax.

anchor.surface_text: Out of the said sum of Rs. 1 crore, the Income-tax Officer companyputed the capital gains at Rs. 81,81,900 and asked the assessee companypany to pay tax thereon.

facts.text: Appellate Assistant Commissioner held assessee sold managing agency, capital gains u/s 12B.

anchor.surface_text: The Appellate Assistant Commissioner held that the assessee companypany had sold the managing agency and therefore the profits or gains arising from that sale were capital gains within the meaning of s. 12B of the Act.

facts.text: Income-tax Appellate Tribunal held no sale but transfer of managing agency by handing back, s.12B applies; referred question to High Court.

anchor.surface_text: The Income- tax Appellate Tribunal, Bombay Bench A, held, however, that there was numbersale of the managing agency, because the original companytract of 1146 purchase was varied by the new companytract embodied in the letter of October 7, 1946. The Tribunal, however, held as follows The assessee companypany was the owner of the shares and the managing agencies. It sold the shares to the Dalmia Co. and handed back the managing agencies to the managed companypanies. This handing back, in our opinion, companystitutes a transfer of the managing agencies. On that footing the Tribunal held that s. 12B of the Act applied. On an application by the assessee companypany, the Tribunal on being satisfied that a question of law did arise out of its order, referred the question which we have already set out in an earlier paragraph of this judgment, to the High Court of Bombay.

facts.text: Bombay High Court held no sale or transfer of managing agency, just relinquishment.

anchor.surface_text: The High Court answered the question in the negative on the ground that there was neither a sale number a transfer of the managing agency within the meaning of s. 12B of the Act.

facts.text: Supreme Court judgment delivered May 15, 1957 by K. DAS J.

anchor.surface_text: 1957. May 15. The Judgment of the Court was delivered by K. DAS J.-

facts.text: Transaction in 1946 after March 31, 1946; managing agency was capital asset, no dispute.

anchor.surface_text: There is numberdoubt that the transaction before us was effected after March 31, 1946. There is also numberdispute that the managing agency of the two mills which the assessee companypany held was a capital asset.

facts.text: Supreme Court held transaction was relinquishment, not sale or transfer; no capital gains u/s 12B.

anchor.surface_text: The transaction in its true legal character was a relinquishment of the managing agency and was neither a sale number a transfer thereof. Therefore, the High Court companyrectly answered, the question in the negative.

issues.text: The short question which falls for consideration in this appeal is whether a particular transaction, details whereof we shall presently state, entered into by the assessee company in 1946 resulted in capital gains within the meaning of s. 12B of the Act.

anchor.surface_text: The appellant is the Commissioner of Income- tax, Bombay, and the respondent is the Provident Investment Co., Ltd., Bombay, hereinafter referred to as the assesses company. The short question which falls for consideration in this appeal is whether a particular transaction, details

issues.text: Whether the assessee company made a capital gain amounting to Rs. 81,81,900 within the meaning of s. 12B of the Indian Income-tax Act?

anchor.surface_text: The question which was referred to the High Court under s. 66 1  of the Act was this Whether the assessee companypany made a capital gain amounting to Rs. 81,81,900 within the meaning of s. 12B of the Indian Income-tax Act? The High Court answered the question in the negative.

issues.text: The point for our consideration is whether the High Court has correctly answered the question.

anchor.surface_text: the substance of the matter. We must of necessity, therefore, have regard to the actual provisions of the Act and the rules made thereunder before we can come to the conclusion that the appellant was liable to assessment as contended by the Sales Tax authorities. Those observations were made in a case dealing with sales tax but are equally applicable to the case under our consideration. Two conditions must be fulfilled before the transaction under our consideration can come within the purview of s. 12B of the Act.

arguments.claim: There was neither a sale nor a transfer of the managing agency within the meaning of s. 12B; it was relinquishment by resignation

anchor.surface_text: The High Court held that there was neither a sale nor a transfer, because the letter of October 7, 1946, substituted a different contract for the original contract entered into by the parties, and the true legal position with regard to the substituted contract was that the assessee companypany resigned the managing agency, or,

arguments.court_reasoning: Agreed with High Court's view on true legal character

arguments.claim: There was a concluded contract of sale from letters of September 14 and 30, 1946; October 7 letter merely changed mode of performance, so transaction was sale of managing agency

anchor.surface_text: His first argument is that there was a concluded contract of sale as a result of the letters, dated September 14, 1946, and September 30,1946, exchanged between the parties, and the sale having taken place, the letter of October 7, 1946, which merely changed the mode of performance of the contract, did not affect the true legal character of the transaction which was a sale of the managing agency.

court_response_anchor.surface_text: the assessee companypany. The learned Solicitor-General, who has appeared for the appellant, has companytested the companyrectness of the view of the

arguments.court_reasoning: Letters formed agreement to sell, not sale; October 7 substituted new contract of relinquishment

arguments.claim: One indivisible consideration for shares and managing agency; sale of shares occurred, so entire transaction results in capital gains under s. 12B

anchor.surface_text: The second argument of the learned Solicitor-General is that there was one indivisible consideration for the whole transaction, including the sale of the shares and of the managing agency. So far as the shares were concerned, the sale did take place and the entire consideration was paid there was therefore a sale within the meaning of s. 12B of the Act, and the consideration being one and indivisible, the transaction did result in capital gains within the meaning of that section.

court_response_anchor.surface_text: property in them. Before any such sale companyld take place, the agreement was modified by the letter of October 7, 1946, and instead of selling the m

arguments.court_reasoning: Parties and authorities proceeded on basis Rs. 1 crore separate for managing agency; bound by agreed statement of case

arguments.claim: In construing fiscal statutes, regard must be had to strict letter of the law and true legal position; no tax by inference, analogy or substance

anchor.surface_text: The second point is that in construing fiscal statutes and in determining the liability of a subject to tax, one must have regard to the strict letter of the law and the true legal position arising out of the transaction in question... If, on the other hand, the case is not covered within the four corners of the provisions of the taxing statute, no tax can be imposed by inference or by analogy or by trying to probe into the intentions of the legislature and by considering what was the substance of the matter.

arguments.claim: No question of deliberate evasion as modification occurred before insertion of s. 12B

anchor.surface_text: The first point is that there is no question here of the assessee company trying to circumvent the provisions of s. 12B of the Act by deliberately modifying the original agreement by its letter dated October 7, 1946 so as to put the transaction outside the scope of that section. The agreement was modified in October, 1946, before even the insertion of s. 12B in the Act.

arguments.claim: Two conditions for s. 12B: profits from sale, exchange or transfer of capital asset, effected after 31 March 1946

anchor.surface_text: Two conditions must be fulfilled before the transaction under consideration can come within the purview of s. 12B of the Act. The first condition is that the profits or gains must arise from the sale, exchange or transfer of a capital asset and the second condition is that the sale, exchange or transfer must be effected after March 31, 1946.

arguments.claim: Agreed statement of case binds parties; Rs. 1 crore is consideration for managing agency separately; cannot argue different basis

anchor.surface_text: the parties and the Income-tax authorities, including the Appellate Tribunal, proceeded on the footing that part of the consideration, namely, the sum of Rs. 1 crore, was the consideration for the sale or relinquishment of the managing agency... In the agreed statement of the case, it was stated The value of the managing agencies was computed by the assessee company at Rs. 1 crore and there is no dispute on this point.

arguments.claim: Transaction in true legal character was relinquishment of managing agency, neither sale nor transfer, so no capital gains under s. 12B

anchor.surface_text: The transaction in its true legal character was a relinquishment of the managing agency and was neither a sale nor a transfer thereof. Therefore, the High Court correctly answered, the question in the negative.

holdings.text: The transaction in its true legal character was a relinquishment of the managing agency and was neither a sale nor a transfer thereof. Therefore, the High Court correctly answered, the question in the negative.
holdings.reasoning_summary: Original agreement modified by October 7, 1946 letter into resignation/relinquishment instead of transfer; bound by agreed case on Rs 1 crore value; relinquishment outside sale/exchange/transfer in s 12B(1); strict construction of fiscal law.

holdings.text: In construing fiscal statutes and in determining the liability of a subject to tax, one must have regard to the strict letter of the law and the true legal position arising out of the transaction in question.

anchor.surface_text: The second point is that in construing fiscal statutes and in determining the liability of a subject to tax, one must have regard to the strict letter of the law and the true legal position arising out of the transaction in question. The Bombay High

holdings.reasoning_summary: Adopts observations from A.V. Fernandez v. State of Kerala: tax only if case strictly within provisions, no inference/analogy/substance over form.

holdings.text: The true legal effect of the letters dated September 14, 1946, and September 30,1946... was merely an agreement to sell and purchase the shares together with the managing agency on payment of the consideration, etc. The two letters did not by themselves amount to a sale of the shares or the managing agency, in the sense of a transfer of the property in them.
holdings.reasoning_summary: Offer and acceptance created executory agreement to sell, not completed sale/transfer; modification before completion changed nature.

holdings.text: the letter of October 7, 1946, substituted a new contract, a contract of relinquishment rather than a contract of sale, so far as the managing agency was concerned.
holdings.reasoning_summary: October 7 letter modified original by replacing transfer with resignation, creating new substituted contract; not mere change in performance mode.

holdings.text: this argument is not really available to the learned Solicitor-General. The parties and the Income-tax authorities, including the Appellate Tribunal, proceeded on the footing that part of the consideration, namely, the sum of Rs. 1 crore, was the consideration for the sale or relinquishment of the managing agency.
holdings.reasoning_summary: Agreed statement of case and proceedings treated Rs 1 crore separately for managing agency; Revenue cannot depart from it in reference.

holdings.text: Two conditions must be fulfilled before the transaction under consideration can come within the purview of s. 12B of the Act. The first condition is that the profits or gains must arise from the sale, exchange or transfer of a capital asset and the second condition is that the sale, exchange or transfer must be effected after March 31, 1946.

anchor.surface_text: We must of necessity, therefore, have regard to the actual provisions of the Act and the rules made thereunder before we can come to the conclusion that the appellant was liable to assessment as contended by the Sales Tax authorities. Those observa

holdings.reasoning_summary: Parsing text of s 12B(1): requires both (i) specified mode (sale/exchange/transfer) of capital asset and (ii) post-31/3/46 timing.

holdings.text: capital gains were charged for the first time by the Income-tax and Excess Profits Tax (Amendment) Act, 1947, which inserted s. 12B in the Act. It taxed capital gains arising after March 31, 1946, and the levy was virtually abolished by the Indian Finance Act, 1949... The Finance (No. 3) Act, 1956 (Act 77 of 1956) re-introduced the section in wider terms so as to bring within capital gains any profits or gains arising from the sale, exchange, relinquishment or transfer of a capital asset effected after March 31, 1956.

anchor.surface_text: It is worthy of note that capital gains were charged for the first time by the Income-tax and Excess Profits Tax (Amendment) Act, 1947, which inserted s. 12B in the Act. It taxed capital gains arising after March 31, 1946, and the levy was virtuall

holdings.reasoning_summary: Historical context of s 12B amendments; later versions explicitly include 'relinquishment', unlike original.

precedents.citation: A. V. Fernandez v. The State of Kerala 1 1957 S.C.R. 837

anchor.surface_text: A. V. Fernandez v. The State of Kerala  1 , where the following observations made are very pertinent If the Revenue satisfies the Court that the case falls strictly within the provisions of the law, the subject can be taxed. If, on the other hand, the case is number covered within the four corners of the provisions of the taxing statute, number tax can be imposed by inference or by analogy or by trying to probe into the intentions of the legislature and by considering what was the substance of the matter.

precedents.case_name: A. V. Fernandez v. The State of Kerala
precedents.cited_proposition: In construing fiscal statutes, the liability to tax must be determined by the strict letter of the law and the true legal position; no tax can be imposed by inference, analogy, or probing legislative intent or substance of the matter.
precedents.cited_holding: If the Revenue satisfies the Court that the case falls strictly within the provisions of the law, the subject can be taxed. If, on the other hand, the case is not covered within the four corners of the provisions of the taxing statute, no tax can be imposed by inference or by analogy or by trying to probe into the intentions of the legislature and by considering what was the substance of the matter.
